No snow. No waves. No problem. ‚ÄúSandboarding is all about freedom and having fun by expressing yourself,‚Äù says world champion sandboarder and instructor Jose Martinez (@jose_martinez_sandboard), who teaches students of all levels. ‚ÄúMy favorite place for sandboarding is the Dragon Hill dune in Iquique, Chile, the biggest urban sand dune in the world.‚Äù‚Å£

‚ÄúI just bought a board for skating around the city, but after a while it turned into a great passion!‚Äù says 21-year-old longboarder and graphic designer Kate Voynova (@katevoynova). ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt talented, but I had a lot of love and hard work, so I started to land tricks.‚Äù‚Å£

‚ÄúWhile you‚Äôre surfing, you become one with nature,‚Äù says 16-year-old pro surfer Kyllian Guerin (@kg_surfer). ‚ÄúMy favorite part of surfing is taking barrels ‚Äî the unique feeling of throwing yourself in a powerful tunnel and coming out after having tamed the strength of the ocean. Nothing comes above it for me.‚Äù ‚Å£ ‚Å£

Meet today‚Äôs #WeeklyFluff. This is Mr. Bigglesworth (@mrbigglesworthrabbit), a cheeky boy bunny who acts more like a dog than a üê∞. #HelloFrom Balochistan, Pakistan. ‚ÄúSurrounded by a desert, hiking up to the edge of a dormant mud volcano is guaranteed to be special,‚Äù says photographer Matthieu Paley (@paleyphoto), who captured this mother and daughter holding hands at the crater‚Äôs edge. ‚Å£ ‚Å£

Embroidery artist ipnot‚Äôs (@ipnot) creations bring a modern style to an ancient craft. Her realistic, miniature food-inspired pieces have a 3D quality that lifts them from the surface on which they are sewn. ‚ÄúI use my needle like a paintbrush and I stitch one knot at a time,‚Äù she says.

Photo and video by @ipnot

See. Hear. Smell. Taste. Touch. #Mukbang is a big part of Korean food culture, and it‚Äôs a big part of creator Jae-hoon Lee‚Äôs (@gongsam_table) life. ‚ÄúI prefer foods with crispy texture, because I can produce more clear and vivid chewing with them than other foods,‚Äù says Jae-hoon.‚Å£‚Å£

Welcome to the Sharona Franklin‚Äôs (@paid.technologies) botanical cake museum, where her edible jellies are made with love. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm drawn to working with food and botanicals,‚Äù says the multidisciplinary artist and writer, who adds found objects like thrift store finds and costume jewelry into the mix. ‚ÄúEach sculpture is improvised,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI work towards melding them into a unifying state where aspects of science, technology, theology and nature converge.‚Äù‚Å£
